major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Energy and the Environment Fall 2024
Drop-in Hours: TBD in E2 2315; online (MSTeams) by request
Conservation of energy, energy balances on closed systems.
Phase change in natural environmental systems; The basics of heat engines, refrigerators, and heat pumps.
Problems of thermodynamics and energy are regularly encountered by environmental engineering professionals.
Basic knowledge of thermodynamics, the science of energy, is required to solve and understand many problems in water resources, wastewater treatment, air pollution, and energy harvesting.
We are likewise tasked with dealing with the air, water, and soil pollution that are a common by-product of energy extraction and utilization.

The objective of this course is to introduce you to theoretical and practical aspects of energy transport and work in both natural and manmade systems, and learn how to estimate heat/energy transfer and energy consumption in these systems.
Develop basic mass and energy balances for closed systems
Be familiar with critical concepts in thermodynamics: energy, enthalpy, mechanical and electrical work, specific heat, entropy
Estimate magnitudes of conductive, convective, and radiative heat transfer in natural and engineered systems
Calculate energy required for phase change in environmental systems
Understand the basic functioning of a range of renewable and non-renewable energy technologies (e.g., photovoltaics, wind & water turbines, geothermal systems, nuclear power plants, biofuel, etc.).
Be able to perform simple calculations to estimate the efficiency of heat engines, refrigerators, and heat pumps.
Apply simplified design approaches to select renewable energy technologies
Understand the issues with, and be able to compare, energy technologies in terms of their environmental impact and energy costs
Be familiar with the basic issues of energy policy
Forms of energy; temperature
Energy of a system; Energy transfer by heat and work
First law of thermodynamics
Conservation of energy
Energy balances on closed systems
Energy balances with phase change; Enthalpy
Week 6 Steam Tables, Air-water systems
Energy balances on open systems
Heat transfer problems
Second law of thermodynamics; Entropy
Energy technologies overview
Energy generation;
Energy storage
Renewable energy policy
Comparing and evaluating technologies
Solar energy resources

course_name: CIVE382 - Hydrology and Open Channel Flow (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: RCH 301
RCH 301
Introduction to the water cycle, flood frequency analysis, design storms.
Analysis of hydrographs and rainfall-runoff response mechanisms in urban and natural systems.
Dynamic forces on submerged structures and low/scour beneath bridges.
Water is an essential resource for human civilizations and the natural world.
To do so, we need to understand and model the processes by which water moves through the environment and in engineered systems.
Climate and biodiversity crises also mean that we need to consider how water resources can be used for mitigation and adaptation in a world where the future will be unlike the past.
Explain the physics of key hydrologic processes
Design synthetic rainfall hyetographs and streamflow hydrographs
Predict streamflow given rainfall and watershed characteristics
Calculate critical, alternate, and sequent depths in channels
Calculate forces on objects submerged in flowing water
Design simple hydraulic structures such as weirs and gates

Jan 21, 23 Abstractions and Infiltration 9.3,14.2
Feb 24, 25 Channels and rivers supplemental

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Field Methods in Hydrogeology Fall 2024
An introduction to the principles and theories of mineral deposit genesis.
Basic technical, economic, legal, and ethical aspects of mineral exploration and responsible development of natural resources are also covered.
View requirements for EARTH 458L
Applied geophysics provides geoscientists with a wide-range of non-invasive methods for characterizing the Earth's interior.

This course is an introduction to the physical principles underlying field acquisition, processing, and data interpretation for commonly used applied geophysical techniques (seismic, electrical, electromagnetic induction, gravity, and magnetic methods).

This course is not only pertinent for geoscientists but also for engineers and others interested in learning how physics can be used to explore the Earth's interior or perform non-destructive testing.
Near-surface geophysics is used to characterize the shallow subsurface for a wide-spectrum of applications.
This application-oriented course covers current methodology in near-surface geophysics, including electrical, electromagnetic, ground penetrating radar, seismic refraction, and well-logging methods.
Techniques for geophysical data acquisition and interpretation are studied and applied to field data.
Examples of the application of geophysical techniques to archeological, forensics, geotechnical, glaciology, and hydrogeological problems are examined.
View requirements for EARTH 461
A field-oriented course on current methodology in the general area of geotechnical or engineering geophysics as applied to environmental problems.

Typical topics covered: well logging and time domain electromagnetic surveys for groundwater supply; magnetic and terrain conductivity surveys for waste materials; ground penetrating radar applications to stratigraphy and contamination; streaming potential surveys of dam leakage.
A pre-lab quiz must be completed before attending each field lab.
Labs will be completed in groups with field data recorded in field books or datasheets.
These data will be used to a complete individual lab assignment.
This site contains over 100 groundwater monitoring wells.
Field lab activities involve:
(3) Measurement of in-situ hydraulic conductivity using single-well response tests
Each lab will provide you with a unique dataset that you will use to develop a conceptual site model of the local groundwater flow system.
• Properly construct and interpret soil core logs using United Soil Classification System, and make lithostratigraphic interpretations using geophysical logs
• Assess and interpret water level measurements through the construction of water table maps and flownets
• Interpret single-well response tests including falling and rising head (slug) tests to determine in-situ hydraulic conductivity
• Interpret hydraulic pumping tests to determine aquifer transmissivity and storage parameters and assess water resource vulnerability
Each module will contain a series of recorded lecture slides and video demonstrations reviewing core concepts and guidelines for the upcoming field lab.
Please include “Earth 458L” in the subject line of all e-mail communications as well as your Full Name and Student ID# in the text of the email.
Hydrogeological equipment to make measurements and collect data (temporary use)
Specialized hydrogeological software to complete certain assignments
Datasheet to record field data
Other data should be recorded in your field books and distributed to your group members as needed.
Do not submit a series of cell phone photos of your assignment!!
Must be uploaded to the appropriate Dropbox folder
Notice of Recording
Participation in Field Labs:
These quizzes are designed to keep you on schedule and prepare you for the in-person field lab and assigned activities.
There will be a 48-hour grace period to finalize the submission of your assigned activities without incurring any late penalty.

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Lab Analysis and Field Sampling Techniques Spring 2024
An introduction to the fundamental concepts of physical and chemical measurement of the environment.
Introduction to measurement techniques including: colorimetry, chromatography, spectroscopy, electrochemical probes, remote sensing.
Design of monitoring strategies, and use of methods to assess validity of laboratory data.
Develop environmental sampling program skills and strategize the overall progression sequence of sample designs with time and space which include:
Develop skills in data representation (parameter specific graphing techniques) and error filtering of real and large(r) data sets.
Develop skills in site background investigations (desktop studies) with particular attention focused towards:
Data mining of existing studies,
Develop skills and experience in atmospheric quantity and quality sampling and analysis, including:
Identify common sampling techniques, devices and limitations of near-surface air quality monitoring.
Develop skills and experience in infiltration quantity sampling and analysis, including:
Double-ring Infiltrometer,
Develop skills and experience in surface water quantity and quality analysis, including:
Velocity-area,  slope-area, and float-tracer discharge estimates,
Slug injection and continuous injection dye-tracer tests,
Depth integrated and grab sampling collection techniques in flowing waters,
Field water quality analysis employing Hach Kits,
Long-term water quality data employing data loggers (Sondes),
Analytical techniques of field sample data for COD, Total Nitrogen (TN), Total Phosphorous (TP)
Develop skills and experience in groundwater water quantity and quality analysis, including:
Laboratory methods and field techniques.
Basic statistical and spatial statistical techniques used in field sampling.
Developing concepts of environmental monitoring design programs.

course_name: ENVE335 - Decision Making for Environmental Engineers (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Decision Making for Environmental Engineers Winter 2025
DWE 3518
Decision-making, optimization, and assessment of environmental and water resource systems, and the design process in environmental engineering.
Multi-criteria decision-making methods for concept and embodiment engineering design phases.
Risk-based system performance metrics and trend tests.
Uncertainty estimation via First-Order Uncertainty Analysis and Monte Carlo Simulation.
Formulation and solution of linear, integer, and nonlinear optimization models.
Sensitivity analysis for decision-making and descriptive (numerical) models.
Each discipline contributes distinct standards and focuses that enhance both the foundational and practical aspects of decision science.
This course is specifically tailored to introduce environmental engineers to decision-making theories and methodologies pertinent to addressing environmental sustainability issues.
Instead, we aim to equip students with critical knowledge and practical skills essential for making informed decisions that address sustainability challenges.
Demonstrate an understanding of the complexities involved in decision-making processes for addressing environmental sustainability issues.
Develop and apply a mathematical framework using systems thinking to articulate and analyze decision-making problems in environmental engineering.
Acquire skills to solve decision-making problems using various methods, including decision trees, multi-criteria decision making, and both single and multi-objective optimization.
Gain insights into recognizing and evaluating the uncertainties inherent in decision-making and will learn to apply stochastic optimization techniques in uncertain scenarios.
Broaden their knowledge and interest in advanced decision science methodologies to tackle complex issues in environmental sustainability.
Theory and Framework
Course Introduction and Utility theory
Systems thinking
Engineering Design and decision trees
Multi-criteria decision making
Optimization
Linear Optimization
Mid-term and multi-objective optimization
Simulation optimization
Decision making under uncertainty
Stochastic optimization

topics: The first part of the project (ENVE400) will include problem identification, generation and selection of solutions, and time management.
A basic requirement of the proposed solution is that it must be compatible with the principles of sustainability.

A basic requirement of the proposed solution is that it must be compatible with the principles of sustainability.
Introduction
Design Process
Alternative Evaluation
Progress Meeting Expectations
Sustainability considerations must be central to the proposed project.
While research (i.e., discovery of new knowledge) may be an important component of engineering design, research-only projects are not appropriate for Engineering Capstone Design Projects.
A five-person team will require a special plan to do more work than the normal four person teams.
Each design team will choose an appropriate Environmental/Geological engineering problem that reflects the interests of the team members.
Teams must select a challenging design problem.
A challenging problem is one where you have few, if any, alternative designs in mind to start the project.
Outstanding grades are possible even if you can’t demonstrate clear innovation in the projects.
Teams must demonstrate that a range of design alternatives were considered.
Teams must quantitatively evaluate multiple alternatives and multiple design objectives/constraints (e.g., engineering analysis and engineering decision-making).

The standard project will demonstrate this alternative generation and decision-making in this 400 course, however, in some projects, it could be more natural to save the alternative generation and decision-making application to the next term (in 401).
Such an arrangement must be approved on a case-by-case basis by Professor Tolson who may choose to consult with your technical advisor.
Project managers are not exempt from participating in the technical aspects of the project, but their time commitment to these aspects will be reduced.
The project manager responsibilities include:
keeping their team on track and constructively motivate other team members,
Instructors will also provide critical comments and motivate students to do the best job they can.

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
HVAC Systems, Equipment, and Energy Efficiency Winter 2025
Selected topics in HVAC systems design with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability.
Heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems.
Constant- and variable-flow systems.
Heat- and energy-recovery systems.
Vapour-compression refrigeration and heat-pump systems (including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps).

Selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air-and geothermal-source heat pumps.
Course Overview: Achieving significant reductions in building energy consumption will be important in efforts to deal with the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of energy use.
The energy used by heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems represents a large portion of the energy consumption of most commercial, institutional, and residential buildings.

This course will introduce selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps.

Recommended Preparation: It is strongly recommended that students have engaged in prior study of introductory concepts in thermodynamics, heat transfer, and fluid mechanics, including analysis of refrigeration cycles and basic psychrometrics.
Students without this background are expected to undertake additional study to acquire sufficient competency in each topic.
Perform simple thermodynamic calculations for selected HVAC components and systems.
2. Explain operational characteristics of selected energy-saving strategies for HVAC systems.
3. Assess the potential for selected energy-saving strategies to operate effectively for a variety of operating conditions and applications.

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Industrial Ecology Fall 2024

Industrial ecology is a rapidly growing field that systematically examines local, regional, and global uses and flows of materials and energy in products, processes, industrial sectors, and economies.

It focuses on the potential role of industry in reducing environmental burdens throughout the product life cycle from the extraction of raw materials to the production of goods, to the use of those goods and to the management of the resulting wastes.
This course will review the environmental issues associated with chemical industries and the roles of engineers to manage these issues.
The principles and philosophy of green chemistry will be addressed including pollution prevention in unit operations.
The concepts and practices of environmental life cycle analysis and accounting will be addressed in detail, together with the basics of risk assessment, management and communication.

Impact of Engineering: An ability to analyze social and environmental aspects of engineering activities.

Such abilities include an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society; the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.

12a Identify gaps in their knowledge, skills and abilities.

Course Overview: Achieving significant reductions in building energy consumption will be important in efforts to deal with the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of energy use.
The energy used by heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems represents a large portion of the energy consumption of most commercial, institutional, and residential buildings.

This course will introduce selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps.

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Introduction to Complex Systems Winter 2025
Professor Paul Fieguth pfieguth@uwaterloo.ca Office Hours: Mondays 4-5pm in E7-6338

The overwhelming majority of societal, ecological and climate issues of pressing importance are complex systems; nonlinear dynamic interacting systems poorly characterized by linear analyses and Gaussian statistics.
This course introduces the mathematics needed to understand such interactions, including nonlinear dynamics, critical and bifurcation behaviours, large-scale systems and power-law distributions.

The mathematical methods will be motivated by extensive examples and case studies such as global warming, energy shortages, desertification, overpopulation, poverty, and economic instability, to be investigated from a systems engineering perspective that will connect mathematical concepts to real-world examples.
Understand the assumptions and limitations behind linear dynamic / Gaussian systems
Understand the mathematical properties of nonlinear dynamic / power-law systems
Be able to abstract / generalize the impacts and implications of nonlinear systems
Be able to draw connections between macroscopic socio-environmental systems

The focus of this course is on the use of quantitative techniques to analyse and solve problems arising in the planning, design, operation and management of urban public transportation systems.

Topics include an introduction to public transportation modes, transit performance analysis, fleet sizing and route design; control of transit operations, and paratransit planning, scheduling and dispatching.

The course also covers various transit modelling issues arising in the Advanced Public Transportation Systems that aim at maximising transit system efficiency and reliability using emerging technologies such as global positioning systems (GPS), electronic fare payment, and automatic passenger counters and pre-trip/en-route passenger information systems.
The historical evolution of transit in cities; the technological innovations which made transit possible; and transit mode definitions.

course_name: EARTH439 - Flow and Transport Through Fractured Rocks (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Email:

Fractures are ubiquitous in geologic media and important in disciplines such as physical and contaminant hydrogeology, geotechnical engineering, civil and environmental engineering, and petroleum engineering among other areas.
Despite the importance of fractures, its characterization and predictions of groundwater flow and contaminant transport are fraught with significant difficulties.
An introduction to the physical hydrogeology of fractured rock.

Topics will include a review of the structural geology of fractured rocks, development and validity of the cubic law, groundwater flow and contaminant transport in discrete fractures and fracture networks, hydraulic testing methods and the hydrogeology of low-permeability environments.
The overall aim for this course is for students to better understand concepts/processes that affect fluid flow and solute transport processes in fractured geologic media.
This includes the proper formulation of conceptual models, its proper translation to mathematical models and to obtain some knowledge on solution techniques to obtain quantitative solutions.
Week No. 6: Analysis of single-hole hydraulic tests in fractured rocks and its implications (Feb. 12), Review (Feb. 14)

One of the key responsibilities of the environmental engineering profession is to monitor, assess, and clean up environmental contamination in the soil, water, and air.

Engineers are tasked to develop, implement, and design technology and best management practices to mitigate contamination, interpret uncertain environmental data to determine the source(s) and or fate of environmental contaminants, and make predictions about how past and future pollution may pose a health threat to humans and ecosystems.
The objective of this course is to introduce you to theoretical and practical aspects of mass transport in natural environmental systems, and to learn how to model mass transport processes.

topics: RCH 211
Emphasis on concepts related to fluvial processes, river mechanics, the relationship between environmental change and river regime.
Fluvial geomorphology is the scientific study of river landforms and the processes that create them.

A working knowledge of fluvial processes has important practical environmental science, watershed management and engineering applications and is relevant to many other fields of environmental enquiry such as environmental engineering, watershed planning, source water protection, forestry, and risk management.
This course will examine a range of physical and chemical processes that create micro and macro-scale landforms over a range of spatial and temporal scales.
Implications of these processes for environmental management in the context of environmental change will be considered.

topics: Advanced Remote Sensing Techniques Winter 2025
Advanced image processing techniques of digital remote sensing measurements (e.g. radar systems, optical and infrared systems) from ground, aircraft and satellite instrument systems.
It is used for global environmental change studies and for more local scale applications such as urban landscape mapping, precision farming and hazard mapping.
This course introduces and develops student understanding and skill at using remote sensing information extraction techniques to provide information about human and physical environments.
The course builds on the fundamentals of remote sensing science and Earth observation systems (e.g. visible-infrared and microwave satellite and airborne observing systems) introduced in GEOG271.

It focuses on current information extraction approaches, such as image enhancement and transformations, classification / pattern recognition techniques (including machine learning), and geospatial statistics models, along with accuracy assessment to evaluate retrieved information quality.
The methods are presented and explored using active and passive remote sensing systems.
This course focuses on the use of remote sensing to map key environmental states.
Emphasis is placed on the application of remote sensing methods and data processing for analysis of physical and human environments.
The course presents advanced techniques for further remote sensing and Earth observation work and gives the student a strong basis from which to develop their analytical skills.

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Energy Conversion Fall 2024
Design of fossil-fuel central power plants, including boiler efficiency calculations and advanced steam and binary cycles.
Review of atomic physics including fission and fusion energy.
Design of nuclear fission power plants including design of reactor core for critical conditions, fuel cycles and radiation hazards.
Design considerations for solar energy conversion devices including: availability of solar energy, solar-thermal converters, thermal storage and photovoltaics.
Principles of fuel cells and some aspects of their design.
We look at the way Canada, and the world, use energy, where the energy comes from, the finite nature of some reserves, and the impact of this energy use on the environment.
Sustainability and the security of energy supply are also discussed.
We review conventional energy systems from an efficiency and global warming perspective.
From the study of these various factors, it will become clear that new energy technologies will need to be adopted in the future.

We then study energy conversion devices and systems not studied in previous courses: for example, nuclear reactors, MHD, fuel cells, solar energy conversion(s), wind energy conversion, co-generation, hydroelectricity, ethanol, methanol, geothermal, ocean thermal, wave, tidal, thermoelectric.
The objective is to broaden the students’ understanding of energy, both in a technical sense and in an environmental and socio-economic sense.

topics: Transit Planning and Operations Winter 2025
The historical evolution of transit in cities; the technological innovations which made transit possible; and transit mode definitions.
System operational characteristics are defined and quantitative measures of effectiveness are introduced.
Methods for selecting appropriate transit modes are covered.
The focus of this course is on the use of quantitative techniques to analyse and solve problems arising in the planning, design, operation and management of urban public transportation systems.

Topics include an introduction to public transportation modes, transit performance analysis, fleet sizing and route design; control of transit operations, and paratransit planning, scheduling and dispatching.

The course also covers various transit modelling issues arising in the Advanced Public Transportation Systems that aim at maximising transit system efficiency and reliability using emerging technologies such as global positioning systems (GPS), electronic fare payment, and automatic passenger counters and pre-trip/en-route passenger information systems.

major_name: Environmental Sciences - Ecology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Ecosystem Ecology Fall 2024
This course provides an overview of the dynamic interactions among microbes, plants, animals, and their physical environment with emphasis on ecosystem structure and function.

Topics explored through lectures and tutorial sessions include the hydrological cycle, biogeochemical cycling, ecological energetics, roles of population and community interactions, paleoecology, and current topics in ecosystem science.
An ecosystem is defined as an integrated system of interacting biotic and abiotic components that occupy a volume of space.
Consequently, society needs well trained people with skills in ecosystem science to effectively protect and manage ecosystems in the face of ever-growing pressures.
Both theoretical and applied aspects of ecosystem ecology will be discussed.

The synchronous (scheduled) in-person tutorials and associated assignments will provide experiential learning of relevant skills in generation and interpretation of data, integration of concepts, critical analysis, and written and oral communication.
Define and explain, in written and oral presentations, the main terms and concepts in ecosystem ecology, such as energy flow and nutrient cycling.
Explain how interactions between organisms and the environment regulate the structure and function of ecosystems.
Generate, analyze and interpret data on nutrient limitation, nutrient cycling and food-web interactions, and communicate the findings and their importance in written reports.
Use basic principles of ecosystem science to anticipate how ecosystems and their components will likely respond to changes in physical, chemical and biological conditions.
Critically analyze published research papers in ecosystem ecology.

Thus, I strongly urge students to use the first option - to purchase a copy of IBM SPSS Statistics for Students.

There is a 12-month rental (extends well beyond end of the course: $ 84.50) if you have reason to use SPSS after the course ends: https://e5.onthehub.com/WebStore/OfferingDetails.aspx?o=adb263bd-0a39-ed11-814e-000d3af41938&pmv=4089c65e-9133-ed11-814e-000d3af41938&ws=4c3b92f6-3b32-e611-941d-b8ca3a5db7a1&vsro=8

Excellent introductory biostatistics text that focuses on explaining the proper scientific interpretation of statistical tests rather on the mathematical logic of the tests.
Biometry: The Principles and Practice of Statistics in Biological Research (3rd Edition).
W.H. Freeman & Co. ISBN 0-7167-2411-1.
Includes a full complement of statistical tables.
Excellent resource for experimental methodology in the ecological sciences.
Experimental Design for the Life Sciences.

This course includes independent development and practice of specific skills by students, such as organizing data in spreadsheets for analysis by statistical software, making choices about the most effective graph and table style to display information (data), choosing the appropriate statistical test for a stated hypothesis and data set, drawing your own interpretations and conclusions from the data, and communicating your own understanding.
